channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Explaining China in Its Own (Varied) Terms
item.description: Zhang Weiwei, whose ‘‘China model’’ theory of development has influenced top leaders, employs more Confucius and statistics than Marx to explain why China under the Communist Party is certain to succeed.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A woman walking along the Shanghai Bund against the Pudong district skyline.

item.title: World Briefing: Kosovo: Slovenia Detains Ex-Premier
item.description: War crimes investigators in Serbia want to hold Former Prime Minister Ramush Haradinaj accountable for the killings of Serbs while he was a commander of Western-backed insurgents in the late 1990s.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: World Briefing: Plan to Train Iraqi Soldiers Is Hampered by Lack of Recruits, Defense Chief Says
item.description: The U.S. has fallen behind its goal of training 24,000 Iraqi security forces by this fall, having only trained 9,000 so far.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: World Briefing: Hungary: Anti-Migrant Fence Proposed
item.description: The government is considering building a 13-foot-high fence along the border with Serbia to stop the flow of migrants reaching the country.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Congressional Memo: Trade Bill’s Fate Rests on What’s Been Missing in Congress: Trust
item.description: President Obama’s trade bill now hinges on a complex brew of congressional relationships, procedural rigmarole and several leaps of faith across party lines.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER

item.title: Dominican Republic Set to Deport Haitian Migrants
item.description: Even before a Wednesday night deadline to register with the government, migrant workers have been routinely seized and expelled.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: Haitians waited at the Police and Interior Ministry in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, to register to avoid deportation.

item.title: Foreign Groups Fear China Oversight Plan
item.description: A proposed law would require international organizations to find a government sponsor, seek police approval for all “activities” and hire Chinese citizens for at least half of all staff positions.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: A Greenpeace investigator taking a wastewater sample in China's Inner Mongolia region in 2013. Legislation would require foreign groups to be supervised.

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Deadly Bombings in Yemen
item.description: The bombs, which ripped through mosques in the capital Sana during prayer times, were another attempt to inflame tensions during cease-fire negotiations in Geneva.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and SAEED AL-BATATI

item.title: Tiger That Fled Flooded Georgia Zoo Is Killed After Mauling a Man
item.description: News reports of the mauling near the central square of Tbilisi came after the zoo had said all of the missing lions and tigers had been found dead.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Claims of Syrian Chlorine Bombs Counter News of Progress on Chemical Arms
item.description: News from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons and testimony at a House hearing on chlorine bomb use presented contradictory pictures.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Palestinian Is Detained in ’82 Attack on Paris Jewish Restaurant
item.description: The suspect, who was arrested in Jordan, was accused of being the “supervisor” of the attack on Chez Jo Goldenberg, which killed six people.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Malaysian Ex-Prime Minister Unleashes Criticism
item.description: Mahathir Mohamad is forcing his way back into the center of Malaysian politics with comments against the current premier, whom he helped install.
item.dc:creator: Interview by THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Mahathir Mohamad at a conference in Tokyo last month.

item.title: Power Struggle in Malaysia Pits Former Premier Against a Protégé
item.description: A battle between Mahathir Mohamad, a former premier, and the man he helped put into office, Prime Minister Najib Razak, has transfixed the nation.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER and LOUISE STORY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia, in orange, at the general assembly of the United Malays National Organization in Kuala Lumpur last year.

item.title: E.U. Agrees to Extend Economic Sanctions Against Russia
item.description: The decision to prolong the sanctions for six months frustrated a campaign by Moscow to win a blocking vote from one of the countries in the European bloc.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Migrant’s Funeral in Berlin Highlights Europe’s Refugee Crisis
item.description: As part of demonstrations happening across the Continent, a reburial was staged for a Syrian woman who died at sea in March.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: An imam led a funeral in Berlin on Tuesday for a 34-year-old Syrian woman who died at sea while trying to reach Italy.

item.title: To Celebrate 50 Years, the Israel Museum Looks Back Much Further
item.description: In a country that seems be growing more insular in some ways, an exhibit at Israel’s national museum tries to convey a more universal message: the story of civilization’s origins and development.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at the exhibit “A Brief History of Humankind” at the Israel Museum. The museum is Israel’s largest cultural institution, presiding over Jerusalem from a hilltop site alongside the Knesset and the Supreme Court.

item.title: Suleyman Demirel, Seven Times Turkey’s Prime Minister, Dies at 90
item.description: A remarkable political survivor, Mr. Demirel dominated his country’s affairs for almost 50 years.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN KINZER
item.media:description: Suleyman Demirel, president of Turkey at the time, and President Bill Clinton during a state visit in Ankara, Turkey, in 1999.

item.title: Greek Central Bank Warns of Financial Collapse if Debt Talks Fail
item.description: Absent a deal between Athens and its creditors, the bank predicted a default and exit from the euro, leading to soaring inflation and a recession.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Pedestrians stopped to read newspaper headlines at a kiosk in Athens on Wednesday.

item.title: South Korean Hospital Scrutinized in MERS Outbreak
item.description: A patient at the Samsung Medical Center became a “superspreader” of Middle East respiratory syndrome after a misdiagnosis, leaving him to wheeze and cough around the hospital.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Nearly half of all confirmed MERS cases in South Korea have been traced to the Samsung Medical Center in Seoul, regarded as the nation’s best hospital.

item.title: Memo From Europe: Teaching the Holocaust to Muslim Germans, or Not
item.description: A proposal in Bavaria requiring younger students to visit a former concentration camp or a center documenting Nazi crimes has prompted debate.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Visitors at the former concentration camp in Dachau, Germany. Relaying Jewish history to Muslims, or Islamic history to Jews, or cooperating on what might seem a straightforward project is always fraught.
